item.title: OOP - Static Member
item.description: Preface I wondered, what if a class, for example A, has two methods, one that can only be call when A is not a instance, but the other one can only be call when A is an instance. Pseudo Code class A; A.do1(); A.do2(); // error a = new A(); a.do1(); // error a.do2(); I looked up for a while on the Internet, and I found there is actually a thing called Static Member.

item.title: 去掉啟用Windows浮水印
item.description: 用管理員開啟cmd後，輸入 bcdedit -set TESTSIGNING OFF 重啟電腦後就消失了~

item.title: C++ Class Return Self
item.description: Wanna make the class be able to do a chain-call class TextBox { string text; TextBox addText(const string& append) { text += append; return this; } }; TextBox textBox1; textBox1.addText("Text1").addText("Text2").addText("Text3"); This is not going to work :P class TextBox { string text; TextBox& addText(const string& append) { text += append; return *this; } }; TextBox textBox1; textBox1.addText("Text1").addText("Text2").addText("Text3"); Works fine! Or you can class TextBox { string text; TextBox* addText(const string& append) { text += append; return this; } }; TextBox textBox1; (*(*textBox1.
